report_title: Industry Report: Culinary Arts Schools in the US
executive_summary: Culinary arts schools faced economic headwinds leading up to the COVID-19 pandemic, bringing on declining revenue. Revenue continued sinking as social-distancing regulations discouraged enrollment, but, as the pandemic subsided and vaccination rates rose, culinary arts schools saw a sudden surge in enrollment as students that previously deferred their education began attending classes. Strong government stimulus boosted students' spending capacity, making postsecondary education more affordable for them and lifting the number of enrollments for culinary arts schools. Inflation in more recent years has slowed growth, though. Still, this post-pandemic surge has more than made up for the declines in the previous years, and revenue has climbed at a CAGR of 6.7% to an estimated $33.5 billion over the five years through 2024, including an expected rise of 3.3% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue boomed as the pandemic subsided
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While culinary arts schools faced declining revenue in 2019 and 2020, skyrocketing enrollment amid the rollout of vaccines more than made up for the previous years' challenges. As social distancing orders were lifted, students who had previously put off enrolling in a culinary school were able to begin taking classes and pursuing a degree.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: A shaky job market has supported culinary arts schools
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The national unemployment rate more than doubled in 2020 as lockdowns forced many companies to lay off workers. Spiking unemployment made it more difficult for jobless workers to compete for available positions in restaurants or other food service companies. In order to improve their prospects, many looked to postsecondary education to add to their resumes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Inflationary pressures have slowed revenue growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As inflation mounted in 2022 and 2023, consumers faced rising grocery prices and utility bills that strained their budgets, dragging down disposable income. With less to spend, demand from consumers for education in the culinary arts has waned. As price sensitivity has intensified and employment has rebounded, students have become less interested in longer culinary courses.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Low salaries for graduates will discourage enrollment
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The cost of attending a culinary arts school is expected to continue rising through the next period. Tuition expenses for top programs, like the Culinary Institute of America (CIA), can cost more than $100,000, while the average salary for American chefs currently sits at just over $57,000. While wages have climbed across many sectors, many graduates from culinary arts schools are still having trouble earning high enough salaries to pay off hefty school loans.

Online education programs have become widely popular among culinary arts students. Because of their flexibility, these programs are able to attract a greater number of students, expanding the pool of potential candidates. While these programs may not replace traditional education entirely, their efficacy points to a forward-looking trend of hybrid-style learning.

industry_definition: Schools in this industry offer career vocational courses in the culinary arts. The curriculum offered by schools in this industry are highly structured and lead to job-specific certification. Students generally attend these schools hoping to become a chef in a professional kitchen. These programs are typically offered by public and private universities and last between two and four years.

opportunities: Demand from accommodation and food services

key_trends: Spiking unemployment brought a surge in revenue.
Inflation has tempered growth since the pandemic.
Culinary arts schools must keep their kitchens clean
The industry receives very little aid
Public two-year colleges are the most popular options
Young adults provide over half the industry's revenue
It can be difficult to join the industry
Culinary arts schools service localized demand
Consumers have moderate power over the industry
Other career paths provide a myriad of alternatives
Wages are the top expense for culinary arts schools

market_segmentation.segment_description: Young adults make up over half of the industry's revenue while only accounting for 16.1% of the US population. These students are just entering the workforce, so their resumes lack the experience necessary for higher-paying jobs in food industries. This makes students in this segment more likely to pursue more advanced degrees, rather than shorter certificates.

Students between 25 and 34 account for a smaller portion of revenue, as they have already entered the workforce and begun to gain experience in their chosen career. Still, individuals in this age range make up a disproportionately larger portion of revenue than their share of population suggests because their growing disposable income enables them to return to college or change careers following their first few years of workplace experience.

Despite making up nearly half the nation's population, adults over 35 only account for a quarter of the industry's revenue. Older adults often already hold degrees or experience in a field that offsets many of the benefits gained by completing a degree in the culinary arts.

products_and_services.product_or_service: PUBLIC PROGRAMS FOR TWO YEARS OR LESS
products_and_services.product_description: Nearly half the industry's revenue comes from public culinary arts program lasting two years or less. These degrees and certificates are the fastest to acquire, making them attractive to individuals pursuing a wide range of careers in the culinary arts. Public universities offer a cheap option for aspiring chefs looking to gain an education in the culinary arts.

products_and_services.product_or_service: PRIVATE FOR-PROFIT AND NONPROFIT PROGRAMS FOR TWO YEARS OR LESS
products_and_services.product_description: Private for-profit and private not-for-profit culinary arts schools provide an exceptionally curated educational environment for students looking to train in the culinary arts. While private schools usually come at higher tuition rates, the shorter time frame these programs entail helps them remain attractive to students who wish to train at a school with more renown.

products_and_services.product_or_service: PRIVATE FOR-PROFIT AND NONPROFIT PROGRAMS FOR FOUR YEARS OR MORE
products_and_services.product_description: For the wealthiest or most committed culinary arts students, private for-profit and not-for-profit schools offer intensive four-year programs that provide high quality instruction from renowned chefs. These programs account for a very small portion of industry revenue, though. While their high tuition rates lead them to generate significant revenue, the nature of these programs makes them inaccessible to the vast majority of individuals interesting in studying the culinary arts.

products_and_services.product_or_service: PUBLIC PROGRAMS FOR FOUR YEARS OR MORE
products_and_services.product_description: Some public culinary arts schools offer longer-lasting programs that can stretch up to four years or more. These are far less popular, though, as only a select portion of careers in food service industries necessitate this level of education. These courses are far more in-depth than shorter programs and include business instruction in order to help prepare students for the administrative side of owning or operating a restaurant or catering service.

tier_2_suppliers: Fish & Seafood Markets in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The level of disposable household income represents available funds for students to allocate toward education services. As disposable income levels increase, demand for culinary arts training grows as more funds are allocated toward culinary arts programs. Conversely, demand decreases as disposable income levels contract.

More than half of attending students at culinary arts schools are under the age of 25, with the majority of this demographic being attributed to students aged 18 to 19 years. The higher the proportion of students that complete a high school education, the more likely these populations will seek postsecondary education. Thus, an increase in the education rate precipitates an increase in enrollment for culinary arts programs. A decline in the high school retention rate poses a potential threat to the industry.

basis_points.basis_description: It can be difficult to join the industry. New culinary arts schools will have trouble competing with incumbent schools that have already established a reputation for quality.
Culinary arts schools service localized demand. Consolidation is rare and demand is heavily fragmented, making this industry's concentration generally low.
Consumers have moderate power over the industry. Culinary arts schools need to offer effective training programs at appropriate prices to avoid losing

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit is high and on the rise for culinary arts schools as a result of the growing prevalence of online courses that enable schools to reduce their reliance on labor.

Class instructors are typically highly skilled, carrying culinary arts degrees themselves while also maintaining several years of direct experience as a head chef or specialty cook. As a result, the large majority of wage expenses are allocated toward instructor salaries, with the remaining portion divided among administrative and support staff.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: RENTAL COSTS MAKE UP THE SECOND-LARGEST EXPENSE
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Rental costs are associated with both leased educational facilities and large cooking equipment and appliances. Culinary schools sometimes own their own properties, but many need to lease out existing buildings, making this the second-highest expense for the industry.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Typically, the steady stream of new workers insulates culinary arts schools from significant revenue volatility. The industry does inherit volatility from changing attitudes towards working as a chef or food scientist, though these attitudes typically change slowly and over long periods of time.

FAQs.question: What are some key questions for owners in this industry?
FAQs.answer: The document mentions questions around regulation (moderate vs steady) and industry assistance (moderate vs increasing).

FAQs.question: What industry data is provided in the document?
FAQs.answer: The document provides a data table with yearly figures from 2005 to 2016 for revenue, IVA, establishments, enterprises, employment, exports, wages, and domestic demand (some values are missing).
